intro.p: Consider the quadratic function whose vertex is the point P({{h}},{{k}}) and whose graph also includes the point Q({{x0}},{{y0}}).

image.description: Graph of quadratic function with vertex at P and including the point Q

content.p: Find a formula for this quadratic function, in vertex form f(x) = \underline{\hspace{1em}}\bigl( x-\underline{\hspace{1em}} \bigr)^2 + \underline{\hspace{1em}}.
(Remember, this is the same as determining a transformation of the parent function y = x^2.)

Simplify the expression you found in part (a) to find a formula for this quadratic function in standard form f(x) = \underline{\hspace{1em}} x^2 + \underline{\hspace{1em}}x + \underline{\hspace{1em}}.
Check your answer to part (b) by substituting the coordinates of the point Q({{x0}},{{y0}}). How can you tell your answer is correct?

outtro.p: Substituting Q({{x0}},{{y0}}) makes both sides of the equation equal to {{q0}}.
